partintro.para: These functions all handle various operations involved in working with functions.

refsect1.title: Description

refnamediv.refpurpose: Call a user function given by the first parameter

refsect1.title: Description
Description
refsect1.para: Creates an anonymous function from the parameters passed, and returns a unique name for it. Usually the args will be passed as a single quote delimited string, and this is also recommended for the code. The reason for using single quoted strings, is to protect the variable names from parsing, otherwise, if you use double quotes there will be a need to escape the variable names, e.g. \$avar.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Return an item from the argument list

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.simpara: Returns the argument which is at the arg_num'th offset into a user-defined function's argument list. Function arguments are counted starting from zero. func_get_arg will generate a warning if called from outside of a function definition.
If arg_num is greater than the number of arguments actually passed, a warning will be generated and func_get_arg will return &false;.

informalexample.programlisting:
\n"; if ($numargs >= 2) { echo "Second argument is: " . func_get_arg (1) . "
\n"; } } foo (1, 2, 3); ?>

refsect1.simpara: func_get_arg may be used in conjunction with func_num_args and func_get_args to allow user-defined functions to accept variable-length argument lists.

note.simpara: This function was added in PHP 4.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns an array comprising a function's argument list

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.simpara: Returns an array in which each element is the corresponding member of the current user-defined function's argument list. func_get_args will generate a warning if called from outside of a function definition.

informalexample.programlisting:
\n"; if ($numargs >= 2) { echo "Second argument is: " . func_get_arg (1) . "
\n"; } $arg_list = func_get_args(); for ($i = 0; $i < $numargs; $i++) { echo "Argument $i is: " . $arg_list[$i] . "
\n"; } } foo (1, 2, 3); ?>

refsect1.simpara: func_get_args may be used in conjunction with func_num_args and func_get_arg to allow user-defined functions to accept variable-length argument lists.

note.simpara: This function was added in PHP 4.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns the number of arguments passed to the function

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.simpara: Returns the number of arguments passed into the current user-defined function. func_num_args will generate a warning if called from outside of a function definition.

informalexample.programlisting:
<?php
function foo() {
    $numargs = func_num_args();
    echo "Number of arguments: $numargs\n";
} 

foo (1, 2, 3);    // Prints 'Number of arguments: 3'
?>

refsect1.simpara: func_num_args may be used in conjunction with func_get_arg and func_get_args to allow user-defined functions to accept variable-length argument lists.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Register a function for execution on shutdown

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.simpara: Registers the function named by func to be executed when script processing is complete.
Since no output is allowed to the browser in this function, you will be unable to debug it using statements such as print or echo.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Register a function for execution on each tick

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.simpara: Registers the function named by func to be executed when a tick is called.

refnamediv.refpurpose: De-register a function for execution on each tick

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.simpara: De-registers the function named by func so it is no longer executed when a tick is called.
